body: another month of no feedback - is there a way to get this to a human to look at ?

It looks like this was broken while solving other issues somewhat heavy handedly in 1.7.4. Please see #5495. Basically every path got converted into a UNC path with by adding `\\?\` prefix, as a workaround for long file paths causing protocol errors.  

Directly mounting a UNC share is therefore no longer possible although VirtualBox supports it. (Edit: does it?).

Lots of fun around this topic:
- #5933
- #6493
- #6598

As a user I would expect all of the below to be valid notation while keeping support for long network names:

```
vm.synced_folder 'C:', '/some/path'
vm.synced_folder 'C:/', '/some/path'
vm.synced_folder 'C:\\', '/some/path'
vm.synced_folder 'C:\\path\\to\\somewhere', '/some/path'
vm.synced_folder 'C:/path/to/somewhere', '/some/path'
vm.synced_folder '\\\\server\\share', '/some/path'
vm.synced_folder '\\\\server\\share\\folder', '/some/path'
```

I read some of the responses re: why this bug still exists and have to
respond with (a) huh - not fixed because there aren't any windows boxes for
the dev to test against - I thought Hashi was a Corp.  This is a $400
problem with a couple Intel NUCs....and (b) don't you have 'any' regression
testing ?  I'm beyond amazed that there's apparently no shared folders
mounting tests for Windows, ala Markus's suggestions.

On Tue, Jul 12, 2016 at 9:42 AM, Markus Rossi notifications@github.com
wrote:

> It looks like this was broken while solving other issues somewhat heavy
> handedly in 1.7.4. Please see #5495
> https://github.com/mitchellh/vagrant/pull/5495. Basically every path
> got converted into a UNC path with by adding \?\ prefix, to solve long
> file paths causing protocol errors.
> 
> Directly mounting a UNC share is therefore no longer possible although
> VirtualBox supports it.
> 
> Lots of fun around this topic:
> - #5933 https://github.com/mitchellh/vagrant/issues/5933
> - #6493 https://github.com/mitchellh/vagrant/pull/6493
> - #6598 https://github.com/mitchellh/vagrant/issues/6598
> 
> As a user I would expect all of the below to be valid notation while
> keeping support for long network names:
> 
> vm.synced_folder 'C:', '/some/path'
> vm.synced_folder 'C:/', '/some/path'
> vm.synced_folder 'C:\', '/some/path'
> vm.synced_folder 'C:\path\to\somewhere', '/some/path'
> vm.synced_folder 'C:/path/to/somewhere', '/some/path'
> vm.synced_folder '\server\share', '/some/path'
> vm.synced_folder '\server\share\folder', '/some/path'
> 
> —
> You are receiving this because you authored the thread.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/mitchellh/vagrant/issues/7011#issuecomment-232104341,
> or mute the thread
> https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe/AAk2KptAAPQqOpBJYCIijNwtJHIWiypfks5qU8PdgaJpZM4HXgtq
> .

## 

-----  vinceskahan@gmail.com ----

I [tried removing the restrictions](https://github.com/rossi-fi/vagrant/commit/c64062ec0796498a04586e052e0684167dfedbae) preventing UNC paths from being configured. The shares were now added to the guest but they were not functional either on Linux or Windows guests. 

From Linux guest boot:

```
==> default: Mounting shared folders...
    default: /vagrant => C:/path/to/vagranthome
    default: /uncslashes => //servername/sharename
Failed to mount folders in Linux guest. This is usually because
the "vboxsf" file system is not available. Please verify that
the guest additions are properly installed in the guest and
can work properly. The command attempted was:

mount -t vboxsf -o uid=`id -u vagrant`,gid=`getent group vagrant | cut -d: -f3` uncslashes /uncslashes
mount -t vboxsf -o uid=`id -u vagrant`,gid=`id -g vagrant` uncslashes /uncslashes

The error output from the last command was:
```

I also unsuccessfully tried to add a UNC network share directly using VirtualBox console. I'm currently on VirtualBox 5.0.24.

@vinceskahan are you currently able to add a functioning UNC network share to a VirtualBox guest, either via VirtualBox console or with the vboxmanage command? If yes, which VirtualBox version?

Currently I'm having to resort to mounting a subdirectory of a mapped network drive (Y:/subdir). When GH-6765 is released (scheduled for 1.8.5) we'll be able to mount just the drive letter (Y:).

I went back to 1.7.4 after trying 1.8 and 1.8.1 which both have the issue.
  Folks have had 1.7.4 work in all known configs up to and including
Virtual Box 5.0.18 r106667 (what I run).  I haven't looked at anything
newer myself.

I can only spend a limited number of cycles removing/reinstalling/testing
on my work computer as I have actual work to do, and since this one seems
to have nobody actually caring on the Vagrant side.  Unfortunately I have a
bunch of developers who need this kind of basic stuff to 'just work' with
no hacking or patching required so we're sticking with the devil we know in
terms of versions at this point until we see folks report there's a Vagrant
version that works again unpatched.

On Wed, Jul 13, 2016 at 3:57 AM, Markus Rossi notifications@github.com
wrote:

> I tried removing the restrictions
> https://github.com/rossi-fi/vagrant/commit/c64062ec0796498a04586e052e0684167dfedbae

> drive. When GH-6765 https://github.com/mitchellh/vagrant/pull/6765

## 

-----  vinceskahan@gmail.com ----

Any movement on this one from the vagrant team ?  Will there be any movement on this ?  Six months is a long time to hear nothing for functionality that is so core to users on the Windows platfom.....

It took me one day to understand why it wasn't working! Nice that this bug is open since 6 months and nobody solved it. Hard coded features are always nice, they are the best way to break something!
In any case if somebody is looking for a work around, this worked for me:

``` ruby
config.vm.provider "virtualbox" do |vb|
  vb.customize ["sharedfolder", "add", :id, "--name", "share", "--hostpath", "\\\\ServerName\\share"]
end
```
on WIndows updating to Virtual box Version 5.1.2 r108956 fixes the issue the folders are still showing the with the \? prefix but at least is working \?\C:\Homestead

This is still not fixed completely.

I updated to current vagrant 1.9.0 and current virtualbox 5.1.10 r112026 on windows7 and the same problem exists, this time pointing to line 1020 in VBoxManageMisc.cpp in the error message.

The 'workaround' of mapping a host drive letter, assuming the host os has previously mounted the desired UNC path to a drive letter, works ok for me.

I ran the excellent test cases in Markus' July-12-2015 note above with the following results, all from a cygwin shell if that matters any:

- mapping "S:" works
- mapping "S:\" fails, you need to escape the backslash
- mapping "S:\\" works
- mapping "S:/somepath" works
- mapping "S:\somepath" fails, you need to escape the backslash
- mapping "S:\\somepath" works
- mapping "\\\\server\\share" fails with the original error reported a year ago
- mapping "//server/share" fails the same way, vagrant constructs the same "\\\\?\\\\\\my.fqdn.com\\share" string the example above tries to do, which fails to work

So I can't find a combination that will mount a UNC path.  Original bug is 'not' fixed.

Hi there. I'm going to close this as fixed. The previous comment (https://github.com/mitchellh/vagrant/issues/7011#issuecomment-263952842) provides a nice list of paths that work and paths that fail. For the paths that need the backslash escaped, there is no way around that. It is simply a syntax thing and must be addressed by the user when creating the file. For the last two paths that reference a `server`, these are unsupported by virtualbox and should not be expected to work.

If you do find that you are still encountering problems, please either reopen this ticket or create a new one. Thanks!

Disagree - I fail to see how something that used to support mapping \\\server\share mappings for 'years' that doesn't support it as of vagrant-1.8 can be considered 'fixed' under any circumstances.

It used to support all syntaxes, properly escaped of course.  It does not as of vagrant-1.8 which is ancient now.  How could this possibly be considered 'fixed' ?

please - seriously - tell us the magic incantation  that permits a UNC path to mount again.  Really.

issue.title: Do not prefix Windows paths if UNC prefix already exists

repository.name: vagrant
repository.description: Vagrant is a tool for building and distributing development environments.

issue.body:
While VirtualBox has commented that they do not support UNC remote
paths (but do for long paths) it seems that remote paths can work.
If user provides UNC path, allow it to be used as-is.

Fixes #7011

body: @vinceskahan Thanks for the feedback. Vbox maintainers have commented that remote unc paths should not be expected to work. However, if given a path that is already in unc format, it shouldn't be adjusted. See #8504 for fix to that situation. Cheers!

I'm going to lock this issue because it has been closed for _30 days_ ⏳. This helps our maintainers find and focus on the active issues.

If you have found a problem that seems similar to this, please open a new issue and complete the issue template so we can capture all the details necessary to investigate further.
